5/ in committee discussion, several legislators asked with concern, ‘where will they go?’ nobody had a good answer for that. in fact, it was clear that many would have no safe place to go. sometimes stigma expresses itself as a shrug of the shoulders.

3/ people who experience sudden eviction from sober houses experience a long list of preventable horrors including homelessness, rape, sex trafficking, incarceration and fatal overdose. the stakes could not be higher.

5/ the provision limiting tenant rights should be removed from h.783 and replaced with a study to determine how tenants who are involuntarily removed from their homes will be kept safe from overdose, homelessness and incarceration.

3/ h.783 allows landlords to turn tenants out in the middle of the night, in the freezing cold, with no money, no belongings and no place to go. giving landlords the right to instantly evict a disabled tenant, often at their most vulnerable moment, will have tragic results.

2/ h.783 unfairly targets an especially stigmatized and vulnerable class of disabled tenants, those living with substance use disorder, and denies them access to court-supervised eviction protections.
